title: Are K-pop idols fake and they’re only doing it just for show? - Quora

response.answer_text: Are K-pop idols fake and they’re only doing it just for show? Let's begin with user u/Oahsnail with a very spirited rant:  Hard opinion there. I won't go into that or my opinon on what this person said. But I will say that it all boils down to how much you choose to care. I don't really care how the music is made. Does that make me indifferent to idol treatment? Am I choosing to turn a blind eye? I've talked about stuff like this before but I'll answer it in a different way this time. If you want an alternate take on “fake,” you can go here: Aspry Wright's answer to Doesn't K-pop feel a bit phony? Today's answer talks about the difference between “fake" and trained. Pretty much all of what you see and hear idols do were taught to them. Personal talents like running around a TV studio like an ostrich. How to sing, dance and yes, how to behave and act. In Korea, there are such things as “manners classes" where kids learn appropriate conduct. Korean Unnie talks about that a little here: #DAY22 [ㅐ, ㅒ, ㅔ, ㅖ] Master KOREAN ALPHABET In A MONTH Idols have classes like that. Whether it's about “protecting” your cleavage when you bow…  Sitting a certain way onstage to keep anyone from gazing up your skirt…  And anything you forget, your members should jog your memory. Here's leader Irene correcting Wendy who got a bit too relaxed on Weekly Idol:  Nayeon scolding Mina on her low cut dress:  Etc. None of this is fake, it's all about “how to behave.” For the respectability of the group and the company they represent. The training goes deeper than that. For instance, idols bomb on part change challenges on variety shows because learning their own dances is hard enough. But they also have to remember lots more stuff than dancing. Imagine being Blackpink Rosé and you gotta know your parts, but also how/when to react during certain spots. There's even a YouTube post dedicated to profiling BLACKPINK Rosé Everytime Jennie Swears in their songs. In the video, Rosé smiles happily on cue whenever Jennie swears.  She lives with Jennie. All four of those girls curse when the cameras are off. It's not like Rosé isn't used to hearing it. She's not loving it when Jennie swears, it's part of the act. It's fake. Even tiny things like that? Training.  And even MORE training! All the way down to the performances. Even the studios are in on it. Ever wonder why it's so easy to create a Stage Mix? Because of K-pop's robotic, manufacturing process, all the shots are the same. And there's a reason for that. Sometimes you want that. When you work at creating a good “feel,” you repeat it because its the best you've got. Here's a good feel - RM comes in…  …hits this part hard and the camera zooms out, increasing the impact.  That's good TV and it's good stage. If a studio doesn't work with the performers to create a “feeling,” you get different results. Here's another version:  Wide shot of BTS goes into a generic close up of RM delivering the same line, but without the visual effect. It's a lesser result.  Not to deviate from the point of the answer, but it's related. K-pop has worked and worked and worked to find out what…well, what works. You don't re-use the lesser results. After Blackpink took a little heat from a not-so-great U.S. show, some fans got mad at the American camerawork. This is exactly what I'm talking about:   Things we may call “fake" have only proven to work in the past and K-pop continues to use them because they have been effective before. The above stage stills are examples of what works well and what doesn't work as well. Yes, it's fake to hear “I'm cutie sexy!” for the tenth time from ten different members in ten different groups. Yes, it's fake to have to listen to “I like you" in every other damn song. It's fake to see the same camerawork over and over again on different shows. Not only that, it's annoying. It's part of the manufacturing. If K-pop seems repetitive and fake across the board, that's because it is. But the alternatives might not be as appealing. In fact, some have proven to be unappealing. When an idol strays away from “how to behave,” he ends up quitting Big Bang. He wasn't trained to act like that. As a whole, it's about creating a tone to the art form. And if it isn't broken…why fix it? Thanks for reading.

upvoters.user_id: Yazmin the Lord and Savior of all Chichis

response.answer_text: GREAT QUESTION. I myself am a really huge kpop fan and have had this question like a thousand times due the fact that I’m a very “wary” person when it comes to people’s personalities, or maybe I just analyze them too much (when in reality some of them aren’t even that deep/hard to get). What i’ve found while ‘living inside the kpop fandom’ is that, YES, there are some personalities that are fake and that are just made for the public but this is not really the artist’s fault, this is just how the industry works, because as you may know, the kpop industry is known to portray an unrealistic —perfect human being, inside in and out— image of idols, however as years has passed, really bad things have happened, stuff has been revealed, etc, most of their long-time followers don’t really believe any of this ‘perfect life bullshit’ nowadays, anyway, but let’s go back to the main topic….. Here are some things that made me realize idols are usually told to hide their true identity/feelings/thoughts (or act in a different way they would’ve actually act). THIS SONG, AND ALMOST ALL OF BTS SOLO MIXTAPES SONGS (AGUST D, RM, HOPE WORLD) bts’ rap line wrote these lyrics themselves, you can search it on wikipedia or anywhere. Red Velvet’s Wendy and Seulgi covering Yeri when she broke down crying in public while being in a ceremony honoring Jonghyun a friend of her and very popular idol, who commited suicide, this isn’t how she’s supposed to act, (even though, it’s totally natural and understandable) that’s why they covered her, also after this she kept receiving criticism telling her she’s not being professional enough (she’s 19). Leaders and members of Kpop groups hating their own songs but perfoming them a million times anyway cause that’s what they got to do, cause they don’t have ANY opinion on their own group content, of course……………. ….And i could go on and on, but the rest, especially, idols “flawless personalities” are just common sense.

I would really like to say no, but I feel like there probably are idols out there doing that. Look, idols are human, just like you and I. That means they, like us, have their weaknesses, their bad moments, their antisocial “leave me alone” moments. They’re expected to be forever under the spotlight smiling, perfectly dressed, and be “the one” for their fans. It’s without a doubt exhausting, and sometimes, especially in a society like Korea, weaknesses means a loss in popularity. Just look at Big Bang - GD is STILL getting flack to this day for using the n-word WITHOUT UNDERSTANDING THE CONNOTATION for it. For God’s sake, he’s doing military service as we speak - let it go. So, we really can’t blame them. We’ve seen and talked about Western idols falling from the spotlight all too often - Korean idols are just like them. There are a few idols, such as BTS, Big Bang, and SHINee, who are unafraid to put their real face forward and show their weaknesses. BTS uploaded their Burn The Stage documentary outlining the struggles of touring and their personal issues while at the same time singing about societal problems, SHINee has been dealing with Jonghyun passing away and has been open about the grieving process and their road to recovery, and obviously, Big Bang has had their public issues in the past which they revealed. But most of the time, it’s not a good idea to do so, especially for lesser known companies. So let’s just keep supporting each and every idol for all the hard work they’ve put in - there’s always a story we don’t know behind their actions, and we shouldn’t be too quick to blame them. Follow me on Instagram: BTS ⁜ 방탄소년단 ⁜ DDAENG (@intro.youngforever) • Instagram photos and videos for more!

Let’s put it like this: How do you act if you know people are watching? Or- how would you act knowing your boss is around? You would be acting like a polished, seemingly flawless version of yourself. This is how idols are acting. Most of their personality is fake, some are actually doing it for show as well. In their pre-debut, the company gathers the group and tells the members what “role” they play; that includes the “happy virus”, the “mom”, the “dad”, etc. etc. To the fans, they act accordingly. But it’s not ALL fake. Their personality is definitely underneath all of their showiness, and they can’t hide it all the time. So while most of it is fake, you can also see some “realness” as well. Going back to my analogy at the beginning, we fans really are their “bosses” in a way. We can decide if we boycott their albums and they lose revenue if we don’t like them. As such, we control their jobs, in a sense. Hence why I asked how you would act around your boss.

KPop Idols are signed quite young, and spend their adolescence in training. Part of that is having it hammered into their young heads that they have to behave, love their fans, never get in scandals, always be ‘on’ in public.Now, this teaches them to hide negative feelings, and to not do anything that would upset their fan base. It hardly means they don’t HAVE such feelings, nor does it mean they always feel happy about constantly going thru a gauntlet of little girls taking fan cams everywhere. It just means they are discrete, for the most part.Also, most of them truly do feel, after years of hearing it, that fans are the reason they are making money. I’ve been to some of the younger groups’ fan sessions and they are delighted with all the people happy to see them. I’ve been to DragonCon, where stars come to the Walk of Fame to sign autographs, and there’s a huge difference. The enthusiasm and thankfulness (for liking their work) appears sometimes (Gigi Edgley for one - so cute) but it’s the exception there.The boys of Up10tion just were the sweetest things, so happy they had all these fans! Give them massive fame and 10 years (like, say, GDragon or Kim Jae Joong) and that shine will go, but I bet money the discretion will remain, and the politeness.Some of the KPop Idols (and actors) do totally fake it, I’m sure. But they hide it very well and that suits me fine.

It’s a very important thing to talk about. In Europe and America, media is considered as a synonym for trash. We are used to celebrities being human and doing ridiculous or even disgusting things, even though they are always trying to look good and act right. In the k-pop industry idols are actually meant to be ‘fake’. There is a need for perfect celebrities and an idol’s job is to provide it. Their job is not only to perform but also to be a role model for people. It doesn’t make k-pop less valuable because most fans (older fans usually) know the case exactly. I think they do it right: people who appear in the media should give us a good example. We all know that these people are possibly not perfect, but we can enjoy them entertaining us. Idols are average people acting very decent for the public. But if someone acts rude or racist or is suspected to commit any crime, fans betray them immediately just like they deserve. It’s fair enough I guess.

Okay. The real answer is- We don't know that. But, I just want to say that, those people who go gaga over how a k pop idol is very friendly or shy or confident etc. - Just know that these people know that there is a Camera focused on them. I have heard the talk that, the companies tell them to maintain an image or create fake personalities to appeal to the fans. For the argument's sake, lets say its not true. But even if the personalities are genuine and no fake things are happening, do you really think that people be their true self in front of Camera? With a lot of people watching? I am not blaming the idols. It happens with every human being. Take your own self or any person for that matter, if that person knows that there is a camera focused on them, they obviously will never be their true self 100%. They will not say things or do things which they would have done had there been no Camera. And also, lets not forget. Idols not only sell music. They also sell themselves. Nothing shocking or bad in that. The industry is like that. Why else will they be called Idols? ‘An Artist’ would have been more than enough. Before fangirling over some idols or even before criticizing them, It is necessary to understand, whatever you get will NEVER be a reflection of their truest self. It is inherently not possible. Because, we are all humans.

This is a question a lot of people ask and are curious about… This honestly mainly depends on the band and what company they are from. Some company’s aren’t as big as SM, who believes that all their artists are disposable… So idols from SM Entertainment may not always be acting like their true selves. Unless they’re a band like EXO, SNSD, or Red Velvet, because those are the biggest sources of income for SM Entertainment with their booming fan bases. Company is a huge thing to consider, because in some cases if you don’t act the way they want you to, they’ll simply dispose of you. Then in SM there are the exceptions like Mark from NCT, who clearly ain’t a disposable part of the band since he’s such a popular member… You could make the argument that EXO members Tao, Luhan, and Kris were like that too… However, that was at a time EXo wasn’t as big/popular/didn’t make as much as they do now… The thing is it really depends on the company…. And of course the member as well… Group’s like BTS. EXO, and MonstaX… They’re as real as it gets for the most part…

It honest is true with certain agencies most idols who have Personalities they are marketed with when they first debut. But over time their company allows them to act themselves. The ones with the overly cute image are told to be overly cute with every company but their individual personalities are real except for the overly cheerful idol personality where they seem kinda attention seeking, to gain more exposure to their group. Like lovelyz kei her image is overly cute where in every variety they kinda forced her to do aegyo every chance they get. But when you hear members talk about predebut that she’s actually very very mature. Also with Tiffany from snsd the market her the shy girl from L.A but over time they allowed her to act herself as the relate-able loud american one through variety shows.

To think with common sense, Kpop fans may be wishful thinking but they are not stupid. In other words, K idols need to satisfy their wishful thinking to a certain degree without being totally ‘fake’. That’s why they put so much efforts on fan service, which appears fake or manipulative to non-fans. But most Kpop fans know it’s part of the performance and they like it because it’s fun, not because it’s ‘real’. Nevertheless K idols are taught to be humble, hard-working, and always appreciating their fans. Saying these virtues are just acting would be culturally ignorant. It’s a myth that people have fixed/true identity, which is interpreted as ‘authenticity’ of a person. Any artist or idol should be allowed to change their perspectives, personalities, self-expressions at anytime, in anyway they want without being accused of not being genuine.

Possibly, but we don't know. After all, there are so many other famous people out there that aren't Kpop idols and the question still remains. Are they putting on facades? I don't know and you probably don't either. But if they were, respect. Faking a personality 24/7 must be really difficult and exhausting. Even playing a character is difficult. (That coming from someone who's done theatre for over 8 years.) But hey, who knows? Maybe that's why they're always exhausted? (I'm kidding, I know that's not why so don't come at me.)

I feel like the Blackpink members are faking their personality especially Jennie, they are all acting like little girls even tho they are young women I am the same age as rose and lisa and I act way differently than they do, and I dont know why but their “friendship" on camera looks fake too. And seriously if any immature blinks are going to freak out BITCH you dont know them personally so shut up, I'm just saying what I saw in there videos.

Many of them have talents. But many people are in for the fame and privileged they get, attention they get. And this is definitely in the mind of many when they were trainee as a young kid. As they progress and finally they debuted, they may start to find all this a hassle and many are unable to find their true self. And their job require them to comply to the character they need to be in. So yes, in the end, many are fake. Fake does not mean they do bad things. But it is more towards they cannot be their true self in life. They cannot show their like for someone. Even dating have to be in secret. They cannot go anyway freely. They just cannot do anything they want.

It depends. In some ways they can be fake because of their company, forcing/asking them to act a certain way. But I believe they are most often being real. They work too hard and (occasionally) get paid too little to be fake for fame. Also, if they lose their face in public, that will REALLY mess up their reputation.
It honestly depends which company. Some companies are more lenient, but others force idols to have a certain personality to be loved by the media. You can never really know, but keep supporting them!
